content.raw:
I think @wwoodall may chime in as well, but the issue with checking `/etc/ld.so.conf.d/*` is that that folder doesn't contain a clean list of architecture suffixes. On my machine, `x86_64-linux-gnu.conf` contains the following:
~~~
# Multiarch support
/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu
/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu
~~~
So looking at it you can see the pattern; it requires parsing the suffix from a list of absolute library paths, which is doable. However, it would be a monumental pain to try to identify which configuration files in that folder refer to architecture suffixes.

content.raw:
It's an interesting discussion. If we give a look at how meta-project or distributions (homebrew, debian, gentoo, openembedded, ...) handle the metadata of packages, it is **not** done in upstream sources. This could be the case of catkin <-> gazebo, as it is the case for debian <-> gazebo or fedora <-> gazebo.

I remember a talk with Steve about having a way of providing catkin metadata for independent software projects (like sdformat, gazebo or even simbody). This metadata could be in a central repository of package.xml files (like homebrew) or even try to make a converter from current metadatas (homebrew, debian, ...) to catkin package.xml.

I see and understand the value of shipping package.xml for ROS users, and the importance of the relationship of both, gazebo and ROS. And don't like to have dozens of package.xml spread all over the internet or local machines. 

About Steve's proposals:

* Keep the file in gazebo-release could be an option and makes more sense to me that have it in the main repo. We could maintain and ship package.xml in gazebo-release, and distribute inside gazebo-doc package or in a new gazebo-package-xml (gazebo-catkin) package.
* Trying to parse CMakeList.txt could be fun, but for sure will be a hell. I wouldn't go that way.

just my 0.2 eurocents.

The possible ways to provide a package.xml file is described in the existing bloom tutorials. The options are

* upstream contains a package.xml file and installs to the location "<prefix>/share/<PKGNAME>"

* the package.xml file is added in the release process (in the case of ROS in the gbp repository), again also adding the install directive

The pros / cons are obvious:

* contained in upstream: any checkout of the sources is buildable - but upstream does not want to include the file

* added during release process: only released versions can be built - upstream does not need to include the file but must add it during the repeated release process

* provided via separate download: requires user knowledge and interaction - the upstream project does not have to deal with its

I've got an idea. Warning: it's a pretty disgusting hack.

Clone this repo: https://github.com/jonbinney/sdformat_package_xml into the same catkin workspace as sdformat (i tested this on sdformat because it is quicker to clone, but same principle should work with gazebo). It just tells catkin to build the sdformat code.

Disadvantages:
1. kind of disgusting.
